	3.2.9  Incident Investigation

PCC promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the root cause of the incident, as well as any corrective actions needed to prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of five years.

	3.2.10  Employee Participation

PCC believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Employees are strongly encouraged to be knowledgeable with the facility's RMP program, as well as, express their views concerning accident prevention issues and recommended improvements.  Employees have access to the facility's RMP program and information resulting from process hazard analyses.  

	3.2.11  Hot Work Permits

	PCC has in place a standard hot work procedure, which establishes a system to ensure adequate controls are maintained to detect and eliminate hazardous conditions associated with fire or hot work.  The system dictates the coordination of hot work, pre-permit preparations, fire watch requirements, air monitoring, personnel protection equipment, special precautions, and other department responsibilities.

	3.2.12  Contractors

	On occasion, PCC hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the safety performance of the contractor is carried out. As this RMP will illustrate, accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning efforts enable the facility to effectively manage any potential hazards posed by these substances.

3.2  Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies

PCC maintains a number of programs to help prevent accidental releases and ensure safe operation.  Also, PCC parallels the RMP Rule by complying with Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements, as specified by OSHA in 29 CFR 1910 119.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program in place at the facility.

	3.2.1  Process Safety Information

PCC maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment designs associated with all processes.

	3.2.2  Process Hazard Analysis

	PCC conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with facility processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses is the HAZOP.  These analyses are conducted by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are validated at regular intervals.  Findings related to the process hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

	3.2.3  Operating Procedures

	For the purpose of safely conducting activiti

es within covered processes, PCC maintains up-to-date written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation, such as product loading, initial startup, normal operations, normal shutdown, and emergency shutdown.  Operating procedures are regularly reviewed and are readily accessible to operators involved in the respective processes.

	3.2.4  Training

PCC has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided continuously for operator certification.

	3.2.5  Mechanical Integrity

	PCC carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks include:

Maintenance is completed by qualified personnel, and any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.
 
	3.2.6  Management of Change

Written procedures are in place at PCC to manage changes in processes, equipment, and chemical storage or transfer.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly trained, and are an integral part of the change order process.

	3.2.7  Pre-startup Safety Reviews

	Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at PCC.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, and operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

3.3  Chemical Specific Release Prevention Steps

PCC has instituted several process controls to prevent and/or mitigate accidental releases from the ammonia produced and chlorine used at the facility.  Passive mitigation systems include earthen dikes, drains, and sumps.  Active mitigation systems include sprinkler systems, scrubbers, neutralization systems, shut-off valves, and other emergency shutdown systems.  PCC also strives to create a culture within the facility that encourages environmental excellence.

3.4  Five-Year Accident History

The following is a brief summary of significant accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP Rule during the previous five years.

	3.4.1  Anhydrous Ammonia

	The only release that resulted in on-site/off-site impacts occurred on February 6, 2014, where a work order was issued to cut out and replace a water line damaged due to freezing water. The damaged water line was directly connected to an ammonia transfer line, which was used for water injection in the ammonia truck loading process.  Due to human error, the ammonia transfer line containing ammonia under pressure was not isolated or cleared prior to conducting the repairs on the damaged water line. 
	When work began on the damaged line, pressure was released through a valve, resulting in a backflow of ammonia into the water line and through the valve.  The event resulted in a release of over 400 pounds of ammonia, which came in contact with and caused facial chemical burns on one of the personnel performing the repairs.  The employee was transported to a medical center; however, after arrival, medical professionals determined that the employee's injuries were not as serious as initially thought, and the employee was released the following day.
	The release of ammonia from the event also impacted a nearby highway by causing traffic to be temporarily brought to a halt; however, no evacuations of

any neighboring facilities were warranted, and no other known off-site impacts occurred. 

	3.4.2  Chlorine

	During the past five years, PCC has not had an accidental chlorine release, resulting in on-site or off-site site consequences, including deaths, injuries, significant property damage, environmental damage, off-site evacuation, or sheltering in place.
 
3.5  Emergency Response Programs

PCC maintains a written Emergency Action Plan, which provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting the workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  The plan contains procedures for emergency response, such as first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification to local emergency response agencies and the public, and post incident measures.  Emergency response activities are coordinated with the Pryor Fire Department and Mayes County Local Emergency Planning Committee.  The latest emergency response drill was conducted on December 4, 2013 and was audited by an outside contractor. 
The facility also utilizes a plant wide emergency notification system consisting of a remote wireless activated rotating siren centered in the facility and hand held radios to assist with employee notification and communications during emergency situations.

3.6  Planned Changes to Improve Safety

PCC continues to improves and enhance the safety programs and culture established at the facility.  The facility is continually allocating funds for a full Digital Control System (DCS) in all major units to improve control of safety and shut down devices.  This system will allow for more computer-based decision making, which will reduce the risk of human error.  PCC has recently expanded the fall protection systems throughout the facility and is currently continuing expansion of the fire protection systems throughout the facility.  In addition, PCC has recently implemented the Milliken Safety Process at the facility and is integrating a
nd refining this process to achieve superior safety performance.
